intro: Cinchona pubescens var. cordata, commonly known as the Amazonian quinine tree, is a member of the Rubiaceae family. It is native to the tropical regions of South America, particularly the Amazon basin. The plant is characterized by its large, elliptical leaves and clusters of small, white flowers. Its bark contains compounds used in traditional medicine, including quinine, which has historical significance in treating malaria. It thrives in humid, shaded environments and is often found in lowland and montane forests.
